text: The primary goal of the CPA in performing the attest function is to

choices.text: Detect fraud
Examine individual transactions so that the auditor may certify as to their validity
Determine whether the clients assertions are fairly stated
Assure the consistent application of correct accounting procedures

explanation: The main objective of attestation is to evaluate and report on the reliability of management's assertions.

text: An attestation engagement

choices.text: Has as its primary source of standards the assurance standards
Includes a report on subject matter, or on an assertion about subject matter
Includes search and verification procedures for all major accounts
Is ordinarily an examination, review or compilation engagement

explanation: Attestation engagements result in a report on the subject matter or assertions about the subject matter.

text: Which of the following statements best describes assurance services?

choices.text: Independent professional services that are intended to enhance the credibility of information to meet the needs of an intended user
Services designed to express an opinion on the fairness of historical financial statements based on the results of an audit
The preparation of financial statements or the collection, classification and summarization of other financial information
Services designed for the improvement of operations, resulting in better outcomes

explanation: Assurance services are designed to improve the quality of information for decision makers.

text: The primary reason for a financial statement audit by an external audit firm is

choices.text: To satisfy governmental regulatory requirements
To guarantee that there are no misstatements in the financial statements
To provide increased assurance to users as to the fairness of the financial statements
To ensure that any fraud will be discovered

explanation: The main purpose of an audit is to provide reasonable assurance about the fairness of financial statements.

text: An audit of the financial statements is being conducted by an external auditor. The external auditor is expected to

choices.text: Express an opinion as to the fairness of the financial statements
Express an opinion as to the fairness for investment purposes
Certify the correctness of the financial statements
Examine all evidence supporting the financial statements

explanation: The auditor's primary responsibility is to express an opinion on the fairness of the financial statements.

text: A financial statement audit aids in the communication of economic data because the audit

choices.text: Assures the readers of financial statements that any fraudulent activity has been corrected
Guarantees that financial data are fairly presented
Lends credibility to the financial statements
Confirms the accuracy of managements financial representations

explanation: An audit enhances the reliability of financial statements by providing independent verification.

text: Which of the following best describes the reason why an independent auditor reports on financial statements?

choices.text: A management fraud may exist, and it is more likely to be detected by independent auditors
Different interests may exist between the company preparing the statements and the persons using the statements
A misstatement of account balances may exist and is generally corrected as the result of the independent auditors work
A poorly designed internal control system may be in existence

explanation: The auditor's independence helps bridge the potential conflict of interest between preparers and users of financial statements.

text: An audit of financial statements is conducted to determine if the

choices.text: Organization is operating efficiently and effectively
Auditee is following specific procedures or rules set down by some higher authority
Overall financial statements are stated in accordance with the applicable financial reporting framework
Clients internal control is functioning as intended

explanation: The primary purpose of a financial statement audit is to verify compliance with the applicable reporting framework.

text: Which of the following best describes what is meant by generally accepted auditing standards?

choices.text: Acts to be performed by the auditors
Measures of the quality of the auditors performance
Procedures to be used to gather evidence to support financial statements
Audit objectives generally determined on audit engagements

explanation: GAAS are standards that measure the quality of the auditor's performance.

text: The review of a companys financial statements by a CPA firm

choices.text: Is substantially less in scope of procedures than an audit
Requires detailed analysis of the major accounts
Is of similar scope as an audit and adds similar credibility to the statements.
Culminates in issuance of a report expressing the CPAs opinion as to the fairness of the statements.

explanation: A review engagement involves fewer procedures than an audit and provides limited assurance.

text: Which of the following describes how the objective of a review of financial statements differs from the objective of a compilation engagement?

choices.text: The primary objective of a review engagement is to test the completeness of the financial statements prepared, but a compilation tests for reasonableness
The primary objective of a review engagement is to provide positive assurance that the financial statements are fairly presented, but a compilation provides no such assurance
In a review engagement, accountants provide limited assurance, but a compilation expresses no assurance
In a review engagement, accountants provide reasonable or positive assurance that the financial statements are fairly presented, but a compilation provides limited assurance

explanation: A review provides limited assurance while a compilation provides no assurance.

text: In an engagement to perform agreed-upon procedures, an auditor is engaged to

choices.text: Carry out those procedures of an audit nature to which the auditor and the entity and any appropriate third parties have agreed to report on factual findings
Use accounting expertise as opposed to auditing expertise to collect, classify and summarize financial information
Provide a moderate level of assurance that the information is free of material misstatement
Provide a high, but not absolute, level of assurance that the information is free of material misstatement

explanation: Agreed-upon procedures engagements involve performing specific procedures and reporting factual findings.

text: An accountant may accept an engagement to apply agreed-upon procedures to prospective financial statements provided that

choices.text: Use of the report is restricted to the specified parties
The prospective financial statements are also examined and audited
Responsibility for the adequacy of the procedures performed is taken by the accountant
Negative assurance is expressed on the prospective financial statements taken as a whole

explanation: Agreed-upon procedures reports are typically restricted to specified parties who understand the procedures performed.

text: Mr. Accounting, CPA, was engaged by a group of royalty recipients to apply agreed-upon procedures to financial data supplied by X Co. regarding Xs written assertion about its compliance with contractual requirements to pay royalties. Mr. Accountings report on these agreed-upon procedures should contain a an

choices.text: Disclaimer of opinion about the fair presentation of Xs financial statements
List of the procedures performed or reference thereto and Mr. Accountings findings
Opinion about the effectiveness of Xs internal control activities concerning royalty payments
Acknowledgment that the sufficiency of the procedures is solely Mr. Accountings responsibility

explanation: Agreed-upon procedures reports should include the procedures performed and the findings.

text: When compiling the financial statements of a client, an accountant should

choices.text: Review agreements with financial institutions for restrictions on cash balances
Understand the accounting principles and practices of the entitys industry
Inquire of key personnel concerning related parties and subsequent events
Perform ratio analyses of the financial data of comparable prior periods

explanation: Understanding industry practices is essential for proper compilation of financial statements.

text: When performing a compilation engagement, the accountant is required to

choices.text: Assess internal controls
Make inquiries of management to assess the reliability and completeness of the information provided
Verify matters and explanations
Obtain a general knowledge of the business and operations of the entity

explanation: A compilation engagement requires understanding the entity's business and operations.

text: Which of the following statements concerning compilation engagement is incorrect?

choices.text: In a compilation engagement, the accountant is engaged to use accounting expertise as opposed to auditing expertise to collect, classify and summarize financial information
The procedures employed in a compilation engagement enable the accountant to express a moderate level of assurance on the compiled financial information
Users of the compiled financial information derive some benefit as a result of the accountants involvement because the service has been performed with due professional skill and care
A compilation engagement ordinarily entails reducing detailed data to a manageable and understandable form without a requirement to test the assertions underlying that information

explanation: Compilation engagements provide no assurance, only presentation of financial information.

text: Which of the following procedures is ordinarily performed by an accountant in a compilation engagement?

choices.text: Reading the financial statements to consider whether they are free of obvious mistakes in the application of accounting principles
Obtaining written representations from management indicating that the compiled financial statements will not be used to obtain credit
Making inquiries of management concerning actions taken at meetings of the stockholders and the board of directors
Applying analytical procedures designed to corroborate managements assertions that are embodied in the financial statement components

explanation: Basic reading and review for obvious errors is a standard compilation procedure.

text: Which of the following statements concerning consulting services is false?

choices.text: The performance of consulting services for audit clients does not, in and of itself, impair the auditors independence
Consulting services differ fundamentally from the CPAs function of attesting to the assertions of other parties
Consulting services ordinarily involves external reporting
Most CPAs, including those who provide audit and tax services, also provide consulting services to their clients

explanation: Consulting services typically involve internal reporting and recommendations rather than external reporting.

text: Which of the following is one of the limitations of an audit?

choices.text: The possibility that management may prevent the auditor from performing the necessary audit procedures
The likelihood that the auditor may not be able to detect material misstatements in the financial statements because the auditor is engaged only after the clients year-end
The fact that most audit evidence is persuasive rather than conclusive in nature
The risk that the auditor may not possess the training and proficiency required by the engagement

explanation: Audit evidence is typically persuasive rather than conclusive, which is a fundamental limitation of auditing.

text: Operational auditing is primarily oriented toward

choices.text: Future operational improvements to accomplish the goals of management
The accuracy of data reflected in managements financial records
The verification that a companys financial statements are fairly presented
Past protection provided by existing internal control

explanation: Operational auditing focuses on improving future operations and achieving management's goals.

text: A typical objective of an operational audit is for the auditor to

choices.text: Determine whether the financial statements fairly present the entitys operations
Evaluate the feasibility of attaining the entitys operational objectives
Make recommendations for improving performance
Report on the entitys relative success in attaining profit maximization

explanation: Operational audits aim to identify areas for improvement and make recommendations.

text: Which of the following statements best describes why the CPA profession has deemed it essential to promulgate ethical standards and to establish means for ensuring their observance?

choices.text: A requirement for a profession is the establishment of ethical standards that stress primarily a responsibility to clients and colleagues
A requirement of most state laws calls for the profession to establish a code of ethics
An essential means of self-protection for the profession is the establishment of flexible ethical standards by the profession
A distinguishing mark of a profession is its acceptance of responsibility to the public

explanation: The CPA profession recognizes the importance of ethical standards to ensure the integrity and credibility of the profession.

text: A basic objective of a CPA firm is to provide professional services that conform with professional standards. Reasonable assurance of achieving this basic objective is provided through

choices.text: A system of peer review
Continuing professional education
A system of quality control
Compliance with generally accepted reporting standards

explanation: Quality control is essential for providing reasonable assurance of professional standards.

text: The objective of quality control mandates that a public accounting firm should establish policies and procedures for professional development which provide reasonable assurance that all entry-level personnel

choices.text: Prepare working papers which are standardized in form and content
Have the knowledge required to enable them to fulfill responsibilities assigned
Will advance within the organization
Develop specialties in specific areas of accounting

explanation: Entry-level personnel need to have the necessary knowledge to perform their duties effectively.

text: The Philippine Standards on Quality Control PSQCs are to be applied to

choices.text: Assurance engagements only
Review Assurance engagements only
Compilation and review engagements only
All services that fall under the AASCs engagement standards

explanation: PSQCs are applicable to all services provided under the AASCs engagement standards.

text: For audits of financial statements of listed entities, the partner should

choices.text: Determine that an engagement quality control reviewer has been appointed
Discuss significant matters arising during the audit engagement, including those identified during the engagement quality control review, with the engagement quality control reviewer
Not issue the auditors report until the completion of the engagement quality control review
All of the above

explanation: The engagement partner should be responsible for the overall quality of the audit engagement.

text: The primary purpose of establishing quality control policies and procedures for deciding whether to accept a new client is to

choices.text: Enable the CPA firm to attest to the reliability of the client
Satisfy the CPA firms duty to the public concerning the acceptance of new clients
Minimize the likelihood of association with clients whose management lacks integrity
Anticipate before performing any fieldwork whether an unqualified opinion can be expressed

explanation: The CPA firm has a responsibility to the public to ensure that clients are reliable.

text: The firm should establish policies and procedures designed to promote an internal culture based on the recognition that quality is essential in performing engagements. Such policies and procedures should require the firms chief executive officer or, if appropriate, the firms managing board of partners, to assume ultimate responsibility for the firms system of quality control

choices.text: Ethical requirements
Monitoring
Human resources
Leadership responsibilities for quality within the firm

explanation: The leadership of the firm is responsible for ensuring quality control policies and procedures are implemented.

text: Which of the following quality control policies and procedures does not relate to human resources and assignment?

choices.text: Emphasize independence of mental attitude in training programs and in supervision and review of the audits
Monitor the effectiveness of recruiting programs
Identify criteria which will be considered in evaluating individual performance and expected proficiency
Identify on a timely basis the staffing requirements of specific audits

explanation: Staffing requirements should be identified and addressed in a timely manner.

text: In connection with the element of assignment, a CPA firms system of quality control should ordinarily establish procedures that

choices.text: Provide adequate supervision at all levels, considering the training, ability and experience of the personnel assigned
Encourage personnel to use authoritative sources on complex or unusual matter
Require preparation of time budgets for audits to determine manpower requirements and to schedule the audit work
Establish qualifications deemed necessary for various levels of responsibility within the firm

explanation: Adequate supervision is essential for ensuring that personnel are qualified and competent.

text: In connection with the element of engagement performance, a CPA firms quality control should ordinarily provide that all personnel

choices.text: Have the knowledge required to enable them to fulfill responsibilities assigned
Review and test compliance with the firms quality control policies and procedures
Seek assistance from persons having appropriate levels of knowledge, judgment and authority
Appropriately maintain independence when providing assurance services

explanation: Compliance with quality control policies and procedures is essential for providing reasonable assurance.

text: An auditor who, before the completion of the engagement, is requested to change the engagement to one which provides a lower level of assurance, should

choices.text: Withdraw and consider whether there is any obligation to report to other parties the circumstances necessitating the withdrawal
Issue a report that includes reference to the original engagement and any procedures that may have been performed in the original engagement
Not agree to a change of engagement where there is no reasonable justification for doing so
Consider the change reasonable if it relates to information that is correct, incomplete or otherwise unsatisfactory

explanation: The auditor should withdraw and consider whether there is any obligation to report to other parties the circumstances necessitating the withdrawal.

text: As a guidance for measuring the quality of the performance of an auditor, the auditor should refer to

choices.text: Statements of the Financial Accounting Standards Board
Generally Accepted Auditing Standards
Interpretations of the Statements on Auditing Standards
Statements on Quality Control Standards

explanation: GAAS provide a framework for measuring the quality of auditor performance.

text: A CPA, while performing an audit, strives to achieve independence in appearance in order to

choices.text: Reduce risk and liability
Comply with the generally accepted standards of field work
Become independent in fact
Maintain public confidence in the profession

explanation: Independence in appearance is crucial for maintaining public confidence in the profession.

text: Which of the following best describes a portion of the auditors responsibility regarding illegal acts by clients?

choices.text: The auditors have a responsibility to discover all material illegal acts
If audit procedures reveal illegal acts, the auditors should take appropriate actions
If the auditors suspect illegal acts have been performed, they should conduct a legal audit of the company
The auditors responsibility for the detection of all illegal acts is the same as their responsibility regarding material misstatements due to errors and fraud

explanation: The auditor should take appropriate actions when illegal acts are discovered during an audit.

text: The auditors who find that the client has committed an illegal act would be most likely to withdraw from the engagement when the

choices.text: Management fails to take appropriate corrective action
Illegal act has material financial statement implications
Illegal act has received widespread publicity
Auditors cannot reasonably estimate the effect of the illegal act on the financial statements

explanation: The auditor should withdraw from the engagement if the illegal act has material financial statement implications.

text: If an illegal act is discovered during the audit of a publicly held company, the auditors should first

choices.text: Notify the regulatory authorities
Determine who was responsible for the illegal act
Intensify the examination to identify all illegal acts
Report the act to high level personnel within the clients organization and to the audit committee

explanation: The auditor should notify the regulatory authorities about the illegal act as soon as possible.

text: The following are examples of error, except

choices.text: A mistake in gathering or processing data from which financial statements are prepared
An incorrect accounting estimate arising from oversight or misinterpretation of facts
A mistake in the application of accounting principles relating to measurement, recognition, classification, presentation, or disclosure
Misrepresentation in the financial statements of events, transactions or other significant information

explanation: Misrepresentation in the financial statements is not an error but a fraudulent act.

text: The term fraud refers to an intentional act by one or more individuals among management, those charged with governance, employees, or third parties, involving the use of deception to obtain an unjust or illegal advantage. Which statement is correct regarding fraud?

choices.text: Auditors make legal determinations of whether fraud has actually occurred
Misstatement of the financial statements may not be the objective of some frauds
Fraud involving one or more members of management or those charged with governance is referred to as employee fraud
Fraud involving only employees of the entity is referred to as management fraud

explanation: Misstatement of the financial statements may not be the objective of some frauds.

text: Fraudulent financial reporting involves intentional misstatements or omissions of amounts or disclosures in financial statements to deceive financial statement users. Fraudulent financial reporting least likely involve

choices.text: Deception such as manipulation, falsification, or alteration of accounting records or supporting documents from which the financial statements are prepared
Misrepresentation in, or intentional omission from, the financial statements of events, transactions or other significant information
Intentional misapplication of accounting principles relating to measurement, recognition, classification, presentation, or disclosure
Embezzling receipts, stealing physical or intangible assets, or causing an entity to pay for goods and services not received

explanation: Embezzling receipts, stealing physical or intangible assets, or causing an entity to pay for goods and services not received is least likely to be the objective of fraudulent financial reporting.

text: The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from error because

choices.text: The effect of fraudulent act is likely omitted in the accounting records
Fraud is ordinarily accompanied by acts specifically designed to conceal its existence
Fraud is always a result of connivance between or among employees
The auditor is responsible to detect errors but not fraud

explanation: Fraud is often accompanied by acts specifically designed to conceal its existence, making it more difficult to detect.

text: Which of the following best describes what is meant by the term fraud risk factor?

choices.text: Factors whose presence indicates that the risk of fraud is high
Factors whose presence often has been observed in circumstances where frauds have occurred
Factors whose presence requires modifications of planned audit procedures
Reportable conditions identified during an audit

explanation: Fraud risk factors are factors that often have been observed in circumstances where frauds have occurred.

text: Fraud risk factors relating to managements characteristics and influence over the control environment

choices.text: Pertain to managements abilities, pressures, style, and attitude relating to internal control and the financial reporting process
Involve the economic and regulatory environment in which the entity operates
Pertain to the nature and complexity of the entity and its transactions, the entitys financial condition, and its profitability
Involve the lack of controls designed to prevent or detect misappropriation of assets

explanation: Fraud risk factors relating to managements characteristics and influence over the control environment pertain to managements abilities, pressures, style, and attitude relating to internal control and the financial reporting process.

text: Which of the following is least likely a category of fraud risk factors that relate to misstatements resulting from fraudulent financial reporting?

choices.text: Managements characteristics and influence over the control environment
Industry conditions
Operating characteristics and financial stability
Susceptibility of assets to misappropriation

explanation: Susceptibility of assets to misappropriation is least likely to be a category of fraud risk factors that relate to misstatements resulting from fraudulent financial reporting.

text: Which of the following circumstances most likely indicate the possibility of fraud or error?

choices.text: Management engages in frank communication with appropriate third parties, such as regulators and bankers
Evidence of an unduly lavish lifestyle by officers or employees
Conservative application of accounting principles
Minimal differences from expectations disclosed by analytical procedures

explanation: Management's frank communication with appropriate third parties, such as regulators and bankers, is a strong indicator of the possibility of fraud or error.

text: If the auditor believes an indicated fraud or error could have a material effect on the financial statements, the nature, timing and extent of the procedures to be performed depends on the auditors judgment as to

choices.text: The type of fraud or error
The likelihood that a particular type of fraud or error could have a material effect on the financial statements
The likelihood of their occurrence
All of the above

explanation: The auditor should perform procedures that are appropriate to the nature, timing, and extent of the fraud or error.

text: If an auditor believes a client may have committed illegal acts, which of the following actions should the auditor take?

choices.text: Consult with the clients counsel and the auditors counsel to determine how the suspected illegal acts will be communicated to stockholders
Extend auditing procedures to determine whether the suspected illegal acts have a material effect on the financial statements
Make inquiries of the clients management and obtain an understanding of the circumstances underlying the acts and of other evidence to determine the effects of the acts on the financial statements
Notify each member of the audit committee of the board of directors about the nature of the acts and request that they advise an approach to be taken by the auditor

explanation: The auditor should notify the audit committee about the suspected illegal acts and request their advice.

text: When the auditor becomes aware of information concerning a possible noncompliance to laws or regulations, the auditor should appropriately

choices.text: Obtain an understanding of the nature of the act and the circumstances in which it has occurred, and evaluate the possible effect on the financial statements
Discuss his suspicion with the management
Ask management to determine whether a violation is really committed
Consult with the entitys legal counsel as to what appropriate action the auditor should do

explanation: The auditor should obtain an understanding of the nature of the act and the circumstances in which it has occurred, and evaluate the possible effect on the financial statements.

text: Which of the following circumstances regarding the entitys noncompliance to laws or regulations may cause the auditor to resign from an engagement?

choices.text: The auditor is unable to determine whether noncompliance has occurred
If the auditor concludes that the noncompliance has a material effect on the financial statements and has not been properly reflected in the financial statements
When the entity does not take remedial action that he considers necessary in the circumstances even when the noncompliance is not material to financial statements
When the disclosure of the effect of noncompliance to legal authority is necessary

explanation: The auditor should resign from the engagement if the noncompliance has a material effect on the financial statements and has not been properly reflected in the financial statements.

text: An advantage of statistical over non-statistical sampling is that statistical sampling

choices.text: Enables auditors to objectively measure the reliability of their sample results
Permits use of a smaller sample size than would be necessary with non-statistical sampling
Is compatible with a wider variety of sample selection methods than is non-statistical sampling
Allows auditors to inject their subjective judgment in determining sample size and selection process in order to audit items of greatest value and highest risk

explanation: Statistical sampling provides objective measures of sampling risk and reliability.

text: Of the following statements, which one best differentiates statistical sampling from nonstatistical sampling?

choices.text: Statistical sampling is a mathematical approach to inference, whereas nonstatistical sampling is a more subjective approach
Nonstatistical sampling has greater applicability to large populations than does statistical sampling
Nonstatistical sampling is more subjective but produces greater consistency in the application of audit judgment
Nonstatistical sampling has greater applicability to populations that lend themselves to random selection

explanation: Statistical sampling uses mathematical techniques while nonstatistical sampling relies more on auditor judgment.

text: Which of the following sampling methods is most useful to auditors when testing for internal control effectiveness?

choices.text: Stratified random sampling
Attribute sampling
Variables sampling
Unrestricted random sampling with replacement

explanation: Attribute sampling is most appropriate for testing internal controls as it focuses on the rate of deviations.

text: If certain forms are not consecutively numbered

choices.text: Selection of a random sample probably is not possible
Systematic sampling may be appropriate
Stratified sampling should be used
Random number tables cannot be used

explanation: Systematic sampling can be used even when items are not consecutively numbered.

text: What is the primary objective of using stratification as a sampling method in auditing?

choices.text: To increase the confidence level at which a decision will be reached from the results of the sample selected
To determine the occurrence rate for a given characteristic in the population being studied
To decrease the effect of variance in the total population
To determine the precision range of the sample selected

explanation: Stratification reduces the effect of variance by grouping similar items together.

text: In comparison with classical variables sampling, which of the following is an advantage of value weighted sampling?

choices.text: Value weighted sampling automatically results in a stratified sample
Value weighted sampling results in a smaller sample size if many differences are expected between audited and recorded amounts
Value weighted sampling is particularly appropriate when understatement errors are expected
Value weighted sampling is less likely to overstate the allowance for sampling risk when errors are found in the sample

explanation: Value weighted sampling naturally stratifies the sample based on item values.

text: Which of the following best illustrates the concept of sampling risk?

choices.text: A randomly chosen sample may not be representative of the population as a whole on the characteristics of interest
An auditor may select audit procedure that are not appropriate to achieve the specific objective
An auditor may fail to recognize errors in the documents examined for chosen sample
The documents related to the chosen sample may not be available for inspection

explanation: Sampling risk occurs when the sample is not representative of the population.

text: One of the ways to reduce sampling risk is to

choices.text: Use an appropriate method of selecting sample items from the population
Carefully design the audit procedures to be used
Provide proper supervision and instruction of the audit team
Use variables sampling rather than attribute sampling

explanation: Using appropriate sampling methods helps reduce sampling risk.

text: One of the causes of non-sampling error is

choices.text: Failure to draw a random sample
Failure to draw a representative sample
The use of inappropriate or ineffective audit procedures
The use of attributes sampling instead of variables sampling

explanation: Non-sampling errors occur due to inappropriate audit procedures rather than sampling issues.

text: In performing substantive tests, the auditor is concerned with two risks of errors of sampling the alpha error and the beta error

choices.text: The alpha error is of greater concern to the auditor than the beta error
The beta error is of greater concern to the auditor than the alpha error
The beta error and the alpha error are of equal importance to the auditor
Neither the alpha error nor the beta error need be considered by the auditor

explanation: Beta error (Type II error) is more concerning as it represents the risk of incorrect acceptance.

text: As a result of tests of controls, an auditor assessed control risk too low and decreased substantive testing. This assessment occurred because the true deviation rate in the population was

choices.text: Less than the risk of assessing control risk too low, based on the auditors sample
Less than the deviation rate in the auditors sample
More than the risk of assessing control risk too low, based on the auditors sample
More than the deviation rate in the auditors sample

explanation: The true deviation rate was higher than what was found in the sample, leading to an incorrect assessment.

text: The likelihood of assessing control risk too high is the risk that the sample selected to test controls

choices.text: Does not support the auditors planned assessed level of control risk when the true operating effectiveness of internal control justifies such an assessment
Contains misstatements that could be material to the financial statements when aggregated with misstatements in other account balances or transactions classes
Contains proportionately fewer monetary errors or deviations from prescribed internal controls than exist in the balance or class as a whole
Does not support the tolerable error for some or all of managements assertions

explanation: This describes the risk of assessing control risk too high when controls are actually effective.

text: How would increases in tolerable misstatement and assessed level of control risk affect the sample size in a substantive test of details? Tolerable misstatement Assessed level of control risk

choices.text: Increase Increase
Increase Decrease
Decrease Increase
Decrease Decrease

explanation: Higher tolerable misstatement decreases sample size, while higher control risk increases sample size.

text: Which of the following results in a decrease in sample size for attributes? Acceptable sampling risk Tolerable deviation rate Expected population deviation rate

choices.text: Increase Decrease Increase
Decrease Increase Decrease
Increase Increase Decrease
Increase Increase Increase

explanation: Higher acceptable risk and tolerable rate increase sample size, while lower expected deviation rate decreases it.

text: Which of the following statements is correct concerning statistical sampling in tests of controls?

choices.text: The population size has little or no effect on determining sample size except for very small populations
The expected population deviation rate has little or no effect on determining sample size except for very small populations
As the population size doubles, the sample size should also double
For a given tolerable rate, a larger sample size should be selected as the expected population deviation rate decreases

explanation: Population size generally has minimal effect on sample size except for very small populations.

text: An auditor who uses statistical sampling for attributes in testing internal controls should increase the assessed level of control risk when the

choices.text: Sample occurrence rate is less than the expected occurrence rate used in planning the sample
Tolerable rate less the allowance for sampling risk exceeds the sample occurrence rate
Sample occurrence rate plus the allowance for sampling risk exceeds the tolerable rate
Sample occurrence rate plus the allowance for sampling risk equals the tolerable rate

explanation: When the upper deviation rate exceeds the tolerable rate, control risk should be increased.

text: Subsequent events refer to

choices.text: Significant events that occur between the balance sheet date and the date of the auditors report which have been discovered by the auditor during the same period
Significant events that occur between the balance sheet date and the date of the auditors report irrespective of the date they have been discovered by the auditor
Significant events that occur between the balance sheet date and the date the audited financial statements have been released to the client, irrespective of the date of their discovery by the auditor
All significant events that occur after balance sheet date

explanation: Subsequent events are those that occur after the balance sheet date and may affect the financial statements.

text: Which of the following statements best describes the date of the financial statements?

choices.text: The date on which those with the recognized authority assert that they have prepared the entitys complete set of financial statements, including the related notes, and that they have taken responsibility for them
The date that the auditors report and audited financial statements are made available to third parties
The date of the end of the latest period covered by the financial statements, which is normally the date of the most recent balance sheet in the financial statements subject to audit
The date on which the auditor has obtained sufficient appropriate audit evidence on which to base the opinion on the financial statements

explanation: The date of the financial statements is when the auditor has completed the audit and is ready to issue an opinion.

text: When completing the audit, the auditor performs procedures designed to identify subsequent events that may require adjustment of, or disclosure in, the financial statements. Accordingly Those that provide evidence about Those that are indicative of conditions conditions that existed at period end that arose subsequent to period end

choices.text: Will require adjustment Will require adjustment
Will require adjustment Will require disclosure
Will require disclosure Will require disclosure
Will require disclosure Will require adjustment

explanation: Subsequent events should be disclosed in the financial statements, not adjusted.

text: Which of the following is not among the characteristics of the procedures performed in completing the audit?

choices.text: They are optional since they have only an indirect impact on the opinion to be expressed
They involve many subjective judgments by the auditor
They are performed after the balance sheet date
They are usually performed by audit managers or other senior members of the audit team who have extensive audit experience with the client

explanation: The audit procedures are not optional as they are performed to draw conclusions about the financial statements.

text: A Type I subsequent event involves subsequent information about a condition that existed at the balance sheet date. Subsequent knowledge of which of the following would cause the entity to adjust its December 31 financial statements?

choices.text: Sale of an issue of new stock for P500,000 on January 30
Settlement of a damage lawsuit for a customers inquiry sustained February 15 for P100,000
Settlement of litigation in February for P100,000 that had been estimated at P120,000 in the December 31 financial statements
Storm damage of P1 million to the entitys buildings on March 1

explanation: This is a Type I subsequent event as it involves a change in the financial statements due to a subsequent event.

text: A major customer of an audit client suffers a fire just prior to completion of year-end field work. The auditor believes that his event could have a significant direct effect on the financial statements. The auditor should

choices.text: Advise management to disclose the events in notes to the financial statements
Disclose the event in the auditors report
Withhold submission of the auditors report until the extent of the direct effect on the financial statements is known
Advise management to adjust the financial statements

explanation: The auditor should disclose the event in the financial statements as it could affect the financial statements.

text: Which of the following subsequent events will be least likely to result in an adjustment to the financial statements?

choices.text: Culmination of events affecting the realization of accounts receivable owned as of the balance sheet date
Culmination of events affecting the realization of inventories owned as of the balance sheet date
Material changes in the settlement of liability which were estimated as of the balance sheet date
Material changes in the quoted market prices of listed investment securities since the balance sheet date

explanation: Changes in quoted market prices are not typically reflected in the financial statements unless they are material.

text: Which of the following is not a procedure normally performed while completing the audit?

choices.text: Obtain a lawyers letter
Obtain a representations letter
Perform an overall review using analytical procedures
Obtain confirmation of capital stockholdings from shareholders

explanation: Obtaining a lawyers letter is not a standard procedure in completing the audit.

text: Which of the following auditing procedures is ordinarily performed last?

choices.text: Reading of the minutes of the directors meetings
Confirming accounts payable
Obtaining a management representation letter
Testing of the purchasing function

explanation: Testing of the purchasing function is usually performed last as it involves verifying the completeness and accuracy of the purchasing process.

text: One reason why the independent auditors perform analytical procedures on the clients operations is to identify

choices.text: Weaknesses of a material nature in internal control
Non-compliance with prescribed control procedures
Improper separation of accounting and other financial duties
Unusual transactions

explanation: Analytical procedures help auditors identify unusual transactions that may require further investigation.

text: Analytical procedures performed in the overall review stage of an audit suggest that several accounts have unexpected relationships. The results of these procedures most likely indicate that

choices.text: The communication with the audit committee should be revised
Irregularities exist among the relevant account balances
Additional substantive tests of details are required
Internal control activities are not operating effectively

explanation: Analytical procedures help identify irregularities in account relationships.

text: The auditor notices significant fluctuations in key elements of the companys financial statements. If management is unable to provide an acceptable explanation, the auditor should

choices.text: Consider the matter as a scope limitation
Perform additional audit procedures to investigate the matter further
Intensify the examination with the expectation of detecting management fraud
Withdrawal from the engagement

explanation: When significant fluctuations are observed and management cannot provide an acceptable explanation, the auditor should perform additional audit procedures to investigate further. This is part of the auditor's responsibility to obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence. The auditor should not immediately assume fraud or withdraw from the engagement without proper investigation.

text: When auditing related party transactions, an auditor places primary emphasis on

choices.text: Ascertaining the rights and obligations of the related parties
Confirming the existence of the related parties
Ensuring that the recording of the related party transactions is equivalent to an arms -length transaction
Evaluating the disclosure of the relat ed party transactions

explanation: The primary focus in auditing related party transactions is evaluating whether they are properly disclosed in the financial statements. This includes assessing whether the nature of the relationship, the transactions, and their terms are adequately disclosed to enable users to understand their impact on the financial statements.

text: Which of the following events most likely indicates the existence of related parties?

choices.text: Making a loan without scheduled terms for repayment of the funds
Discussing merger terms with a company that is a major competitor
Selling real est ate at a price that differs significantly from its book value
Borrowing a large sum of money at a variable rate of interest

explanation: Making a loan without scheduled terms for repayment is a strong indicator of a related party transaction because it suggests terms that are not typical of an arm's-length transaction. This type of arrangement often occurs between related parties where formal terms might not be necessary due to the relationship between the parties.

text: After determining that a related party transaction has, in fact, occurred, an auditor should

choices.text: Obtain an understanding of the busines s purpose of the transactions
Substantiate that the transaction was consummated on terms equivalent to an arms -length transaction
Add a separate paragraph to the auditors report to explain the transaction
Perform analytical procedures to verify whether similar transactions occurred, but were not recorded

explanation: After identifying a related party transaction, the auditor should first understand its business purpose. This understanding helps assess whether the transaction appears reasonable and whether it has been properly recorded and disclosed in the financial statements.

text: The main purpose of management representations is to

choices.text: Shift responsibility for financial statements from the auditors to management
Shift responsibility for financial statements from the manageme nt to auditors
Provide a substitute source of audit evidence for substantive procedures that auditors would otherwise perform
Impress on management its ultimate responsibility for the financial statements and disclosures

explanation: Management representations serve to emphasize management's ultimate responsibility for the financial statements and disclosures. While they provide audit evidence, their primary purpose is to ensure management acknowledges its responsibility for the financial statements.

text: A purpose of a management represen tation letter is to reduce

choices.text: Audit risk to an aggregate level of misstatement that could be considered material
An auditors responsibility to detect material misstatements only to the extent that the letter is relied on
The possibility of misunderstanding c oncerning managements responsibility for the financial statements
The scope of an auditors procedures concerning related party transactions and subsequent events

explanation: The management representation letter helps reduce the possibility of misunderstandings about management's responsibilities for the financial statements. It serves as a formal acknowledgment of management's responsibilities and commitments.

text: A representation letter issued by a client

choices.text: Is essential for the preparation of the audit pr ogram
Is a substitute for testing
Does not reduce the auditors responsibility
Reduces the auditors responsibility only to the extent that it is relied upon

explanation: A representation letter does not reduce the auditor's responsibility. It is a form of audit evidence that complements other audit procedures but does not replace them or reduce the auditor's overall responsibility.

text: When considering the use of managements written representations as audit evidence about the completeness assertion, the auditor should understand that such representations

choices.text: Constitute sufficient appropriate audit evidence to support the assertion when considered in combination with a sufficiently low assessed level of control risk
Are not part of the audit evidence considered to support th e assertion
Replace a low assessed level of control risk as audit evidence to support the assertion
Complement, but do not replace, substantive tests designed to support the assertion

explanation: Management representations complement but do not replace substantive tests. They are one form of audit evidence that should be used in conjunction with other audit procedures to support the completeness assertion.

text: Which of the following matters would an auditor most likely include in a management representation letter?

choices.text: Communications with the audit committee concerning weaknesses in the internal control structure
The completeness and availability of minutes of stockholders and directors meetings
Plans to acquire or merge with other e ntities in the subsequent year
Managements acknowledgment of its responsibility for the detection of employee fraud

explanation: The completeness and availability of minutes of stockholders and directors meetings is a matter that should be included in the management representation letter. This is important because these minutes may contain information relevant to the financial statements.

text: Which of the following statements best describes the auditors responsibility concerning the appropriateness of the going concern assumption in the preparation of the financial statements?

choices.text: The auditors responsibility is to make a specific assessment of the entitys ability to continue as a going concern
The auditors responsibility is to predict future events or conditions that may cause the entity to cease to continue as a going concern

The auditors responsibility is to consider the appropriateness of managements use of the going concern assumption and consider whether there are material uncertainties about the entitys ability to continue as a going concern that need to be disclosed in the financial statements
The auditors responsibility is to give a guarantee in the audit report that the entity has the ability to continue as a going concern

explanation: The auditor's responsibility is to evaluate management's use of the going concern assumption and assess whether there are material uncertainties that need to be disclosed. The auditor does not make predictions about the future or provide guarantees.

text: When the auditor concludes that there is substantial doubt about a continuing audit clients ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time, the auditors responsibility is to

choices.text: Consider the adequacy of disclosures about the clients possible inability to continue as a g oing concern
Issue a qualified or adverse opinion, depending upon materiality, due to the possible effects of the financial statements
Report to the clients audit committee that managements accounting estimates may need to be adjusted
Reissue the prior y ears auditors report and add an emphasis of matter paragraph that specifically refers to substantial doubt and going concern

explanation: When there is substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern, the auditor's primary responsibility is to evaluate whether the financial statements adequately disclose this uncertainty. The auditor should assess whether the disclosures are sufficient to inform users about the situation.

text: Which of the following audit procedures would most likely assist an auditor in identifying conditions and events that may indicate there could be substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continue as a going concern?

choices.text: Confirmation of bank balances
Confirmation of accounts receivable from major customers
Reconciliation of interest expense with debt outstanding
Review of compliance with terms of debt agreements

explanation: Reviewing compliance with terms of debt agreements helps identify potential going concern issues by revealing whether the entity is meeting its financial obligations and maintaining required financial ratios or covenants.

text: Which of the following auditing procedures most likely would assist an auditor in identifying conditions and events that may indicate substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continue as a going concern?

choices.text: Inspecting title documents to verify whether any assets are pledged as collateral
Confirming with third parties the details of arrangements to maintain financial support
Reconciling the cash balance per books with the cut -off bank statement and the bank con firmation
Comparing the entitys depreciation and asset capitalization policies to other entities in the industry

explanation: Confirming with third parties about financial support arrangements helps assess whether the entity has access to necessary funding to continue operations, which is crucial for evaluating going concern status.

text: Which of the following conditions or events most likely would cause an auditor to have substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continu e as a going concern?

choices.text: Cash flows from operating activities are negative
Stock dividends replace annual cash dividends
Significant related party transactions are pervasive
Research and development projects are postponed

explanation: Negative cash flows from operating activities are a significant indicator of potential going concern issues as they suggest the entity may not be able to generate sufficient cash to meet its obligations.

text: Which of the following conditions or events most likely would cause an auditor to have substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continue as a going concern?

choices.text: Restrictions on the disposal of principal assets are present
Usual trade credit from suppliers is denied
Significant related party transactions are pervasive
Arrearages in principal stock dividends are paid

explanation: Denial of usual trade credit from suppliers is a significant indicator of going concern issues as it suggests that suppliers have lost confidence in the entity's ability to meet its obligations.

text: An auditor believes that there is substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time. In evaluating the enti tys plans for dealing with the adverse effects of future conditions and events, the auditor most likely would consider, as a mitigating factor, the entitys plans to

choices.text: Repurchase the entitys stock at a price below its book value
Issue stock options to key executives
Lease rather than purchase operating facilities
Accelerate the due date of an existing mortgage

explanation: Leasing rather than purchasing operating facilities can be a mitigating factor as it reduces the need for large capital expenditures and provides more flexibility in managing cash flows.

text: X, CPA, believes that there is substantial doubt about the ability of a company to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period of time. In evaluating the companys plans for dealing with the adverse effects of future conditions and events, X most likely would consider, as a mitigating factor, the companys plans to

choices.text: Discuss with lenders the terms of all debt and loan agreements
Strengthen internal controls over cash disburs ements
Purchase production facilities currently being leased from a related party
Postpone expenditures for research and development projects

explanation: Discussing with lenders about debt and loan agreements can be a mitigating factor as it may lead to more favorable terms or additional financing that could help the entity continue operations.

text: The adverse effects of events causing an auditor to believe there is substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continue as a going concern would most likely be mitigated by evidence relating to the

choices.text: Ability to expand operations into new product lines in the future
Feasibility of plans to purchase leased equipment at less than market value
Marketability of assets that management plans to sell
Committed arrangements to convert preferred stock to long -term debt

explanation: The marketability of assets that management plans to sell is a crucial mitigating factor as it indicates the entity's ability to generate cash through asset sales if needed.

text: Which of the following procedures would an auditor most likely perform to obtain evidence about the occurrence of subsequent events?

choices.text: Recomputing a sample of large -peso transactions occurring after year -end for arithmetic accuracy
Investigating changes in stockholders equity occurring after year -end
Inquiring of the entitys legal counsel concerning litigation, claims and assessment arising after yea r- end
Confirming bank accounts established after year -end

explanation: Inquiring of legal counsel about post-year-end litigation and claims is a key procedure for identifying subsequent events that may require adjustment or disclosure in the financial statements.

text: The primary reason an auditor requests that letters of inquiry be sent to a clients attorneys is to provide the auditor with

choices.text: A description and evaluation of litigation, claims and assessments that existed at the balance sheet date
The attorneys opinions of the clients historical experiences in recent similar litigation
Corroboration of the information furnished by management about litigation, claims and assessments
The probable outcome of asserte d claims and pending or threatened litigation

explanation: The primary purpose of the letter of inquiry is to obtain information about litigation, claims, and assessments that existed at the balance sheet date, which is essential for proper financial statement presentation.

text: The letter of audit inquiry should be

choices.text: Prepared and sent by the auditor
Prepared by management and sent by the auditor
Prepared and sent by management
Prepared by the auditor and sent by management

explanation: The letter of audit inquiry should be prepared by the auditor but sent by management to maintain the attorney-client privilege and ensure proper communication.

text: Auditors often request that the audit client send a letter of inquiry to those attorneys who have been consulted with respect to litigation, claims, or assessments. The primary reason for this request is to provide the auditors with

choices.text: An estimate of the doll ar amount of the probable loss
An expert opinion as to whether a loss is possible, probable or remote
Information concerning the progress of cases to date
Corroborative audit evidence

explanation: The primary purpose of the letter of inquiry is to obtain corroborative audit evidence about litigation, claims, and assessments from an independent source.

text: The refusal of a clients lawyer to provide a representation on the leg ality of a particular act committed by the client is ordinarily

choices.text: Proper grounds to withdraw from the engagement
Insufficient reason to modify the auditors report because of the lawyers obligation of confidentiality
Considered to be a scope limitation
Sufficient reason to issue a subject to opinion

explanation: A lawyer's refusal to provide representations is considered a scope limitation because it prevents the auditor from obtaining necessary audit evidence about potential legal issues.

text: After issuing a report, an auditor has no obligation to make continuing inquiries or perform other procedures concerning the audited financial statements, unless

choices.text: Information, which existed at the report date a nd may affect the report, comes to the auditors attention
Management of the entity requests the auditor to reissue the auditors report
Information about an event that occurred after the date of the auditors report comes to the auditors attention
Final determinations or resolutions are made of contingencies that had been disclosed in the financial statements

explanation: The auditor has a continuing responsibility to investigate if information that existed at the report date and may affect the report comes to their attention after the report is issued.

text: An auditor concludes that a substantive auditing procedure considered necessary during the prior periods audit was omitted. Which of the following factors would most likely cause the auditor promptly to apply the omitted procedure?

choices.text: Which of the following factors would most likely cause the auditor promptly to apply the omitted procedure?
There are no alternative procedures available to provide the same evidence as the omitted procedure
The omission of the procedure impairs the auditors present a bility to support the previously expressed opinion
The source documents needed to perform the omitted procedure are still available

explanation: If the omitted procedure impairs the auditor's ability to support the previously expressed opinion, the auditor should promptly apply the procedure to maintain the integrity of the audit opinion.

text: An auditor is considering whether the omis sion of a substantive procedure considered necessary at the time of an audit may impair the auditors present ability to support the previously expressed opinion. The auditor need not apply the omitted procedure if the

choices.text: Financial statements and auditors re port were not distributed beyond management and the board of directors
Auditors previously expressed opinion was qualified because of a departure from GAAP
Results of other procedures that were applied tend to compensate for the procedure omitted
Omission is due to unreasonable delays by client personnel in providing data on a timely basis

explanation: If other procedures provide sufficient evidence to support the opinion, the auditor need not apply the omitted procedure as the audit objectives have been met through alternative means.

text: Which of the following statements is not correct about the unmodified audit report on the financial statements?

choices.text: The auditors report shall include a se ction with a heading Managements Responsibility for the financial statements
The auditors report shall include a section with a heading Auditors Responsibility
The auditors report shall include a section with a heading Introduction
The auditors report shall include a section with a heading Opinion

explanation: The unmodified audit report does not include a section with a heading "Introduction." The standard report includes sections for Management's Responsibility, Auditor's Responsibility, and Opinion.

text: The Opinion paragraph in the auditors report would normally include the following, except

choices.text: Identification of the financial statements audited
Should refer to the summary of significant policies and o ther explanatory notes
Date and period covered by the financial statements
A description of the work to be performed by the auditor

explanation: The Opinion paragraph should not include a description of the work to be performed by the auditor. This would be inappropriate as the work has already been performed when the opinion is issued.

text: How are managements responsibility and the auditors responsibility represented in the auditors report? Management Responsibility Auditors Responsibility

choices.text: Explicitly Explicitly
Implicitly Implicitly
Implicitly Explicitly
Explicitly Implicitly

explanation: Both management's responsibility and the auditor's responsibility are explicitly stated in the auditor's report to ensure clear communication of each party's role.

text: PSA 700 requires the auditors report to describe managements responsibility for the financial statements. The description shall include an explanation that management is responsible for the preparation of the financial statements and

choices.text: For selecting and applying appropriate accounting policies
For such internal control as it determines necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement
For making accounting estimates that are reasonable in the circumstances
Preventing collusion among employees

explanation: PSA 700 requires that management's responsibility includes establishing and maintaining internal control necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements free from material misstatement.

text: The Auditors Responsibility paragraph in the auditors report would normally include the following, except

choices.text: Statement that the audit was conducted in accordance with PSAs
Statement that the audit was planned and performed to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement
Statement by the auditor that the audit provides a basis for the opinion
Statement that the audit includes examining on a detailed basis evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in t he financial statements

explanation: The Auditor's Responsibility paragraph should not include a statement about examining evidence on a detailed basis, as this would be too specific and could create unrealistic expectations about the nature of audit procedures.

text: An auditor should disclose the substantive reasons for expressing an opinion in a separate paragraph

choices.text: Preceding the managements responsibility for the financial statements
Preceding the opinion paragraph
Following the opinion paragraph
Within the notes to the financi al statements

explanation: The substantive reasons for expressing an opinion should be disclosed in a separate paragraph preceding the opinion paragraph to provide context for the opinion that follows.

text: The O ther Matter paragraph is used by the auditor

choices.text: To draw the readers attention to a matter presented in the financial statements
To draw the readers attention to a matter disclosed in the notes to the financial statements
To draw the readers attention to a matter not presented or disclosed in the financial statements
To draw the readers attention to a matter that gives rise to a modification of an opinion

explanation: The Other Matter paragraph is used to draw attention to matters that are not presented or disclosed in the financial statements but are relevant to users' understanding of the audit, the auditor's responsibilities, or the auditor's report.

text: When financial statements contain material misstatements, the auditors report may contain Qualified Opinion Adverse Opinion Disclaimer of Opinion

choices.text: Yes No Yes
Yes Yes No
No No Yes
Yes Yes Yes

explanation: When financial statements contain material misstatements, the auditor may issue a qualified opinion, an adverse opinion, or a disclaimer of opinion, depending on the nature and pervasiveness of the misstatements.

text: When the auditor knows that the financial statements may be misleading because they were not prepared in conformity with financial reporting standards, he or she must issue

choices.text: A qualified opinion
An adverse opinion
A disclaimer of opinion
A qualified or an adverse opinion, depending on the materiality and pervasiveness

explanation: The auditor must issue either a qualified or adverse opinion when financial statements are not prepared in conformity with financial reporting standards, with the choice depending on whether the effects are material but not pervasive (qualified) or material and pervasive (adverse).

text: Auditors found that the entity has not capitalized a material amount of leases in the financial statements. When considering the materiality of this departure from financial reporting standards, the auditors would choose between which reporting options?

choices.text: Unqualified opinion or disclaimer of opinion
Unqualified opinion or qualified opinion
Emphasis paragraph with unqualified opinion or an adverse opinion
Qualified opinion or adverse opinion

explanation: When there is a material departure from financial reporting standards, the auditor must choose between a qualified opinion (if the effects are material but not pervasive) or an adverse opinion (if the effects are material and pervasive).

text: An auditor would issue an adverse opinion if

choices.text: The audit was begun by other independent auditors who withdrew from the engagement
A qualified opinion cannot be given because the auditor lacks independence
The restriction on the scope of the audit was significant
The statements taken as a whole do not fairly present the financial condition and results of operations of the company

explanation: An adverse opinion is issued when the auditor concludes that the financial statements taken as a whole do not fairly present the financial condition and results of operations, typically due to material and pervasive misstatements.

text: When the auditor is unable to obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence because of client -imposed limitation, the auditors report may contain Qualified Opinion Adverse Opinion Disclaimer of Opinion

choices.text: Yes No Yes
Yes Yes No
No No Yes
Yes Yes Yes

explanation: When there is a client-imposed limitation, the auditor may issue a qualified opinion, adverse opinion, or disclaimer of opinion, depending on the nature and pervasiveness of the limitation and its effects on the financial statements.

text: Restrictions imposed by a client prohibit the observation of physical inventories, which account for 35 of all assets. Alternative audit procedures cannot be applied, although the auditor was able to examine satisfactory evidence for all other items in the financial statements. The auditor should issue aan

choices.text: Except for qualified opinion
Disclaimer of opinion
Unqualified opinion with a separate explanatory paragraph
Unqualified opinion with an explanation in the scope paragraph

explanation: When the auditor cannot observe physical inventory and alternative procedures are not possible, a qualified opinion is appropriate as the scope limitation affects a specific aspect of the financial statements but is not pervasive.

text: A limitation on the scope of the audit sufficient to preclude an unqualified opinion will always result when management

choices.text: Asks the auditor to report on the balance sheet and not on the other basic financial statements
Refuses to permit its lawyer to respond to the letter of audit inquiry
Discloses material related party transactions in the notes to the financial statements
Knows that confirmation of ac counts receivable is not feasible

explanation: A refusal to allow the lawyer to respond to the letter of audit inquiry constitutes a scope limitation that precludes an unqualified opinion, as it prevents the auditor from obtaining necessary evidence about litigation and claims.

text: When the auditor concludes that the use of the going concern assumption is appropriate in the circumstances, but material uncertainty exists, the auditor should

choices.text: Issue either qualified or adverse opinion
Consider the adequacy of disclosure in the notes to financial statements
Report to the audit committee the need to adjust management estimates
Reissue the prior years audit report and add an emphasis of a matter paragraph

explanation: When there is a material uncertainty about going concern, the auditor should first consider whether the uncertainty is adequately disclosed in the notes to the financial statements.

text: When an auditor of financial statements has substantial doubt about an entitys ability to continue as a going concern because of the probable discontinuance of operations, the auditor most likely would express a qualified opinion if

choices.text: The effects of the adverse financial conditions l ikely will cause a bankruptcy filing
Information about the entitys ability to continue as a going concern is not disclosed
Management has no plans to reduce or delay future expenditures
Negative trends and recurring operating losses appear to be irreversible

explanation: If the entity's ability to continue as a going concern is not adequately disclosed in the financial statements, the auditor should express a qualified opinion due to the inadequate disclosure.
